intro: Malvastrum tarapacanum, commonly known as the Andean marshmallow, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its woolly, hairy leaves. The plant produces showy, pink or purple flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in saline and alkaline soils, often found in coastal areas and salt flats. Due to its unique adaptations, it is considered an important species for ecological studies in harsh environments.
